instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1932: What is A1932? A1932 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2018, 2019 with EMC 3184, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01521..
definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3S: What is PP3V3_G3S? PP3V3_G3S is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3S standby state. .
definitions.PP0V9_SSD: What is PP0V9_SSD? PP0V9_SSD is a power rail that powers the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on Macbooks with soldered on storage and must be present for the SSD to show up. .
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that puls 20V from ampmeter, but only consumes 0.20A from bench PSU.

I already tried the revive and restore without sucess. Can it be T2 related problem?

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Any history available?
Can complete DFU, or get error (which)?
Do you get G3S and SSD voltages?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hi,

No history. Client says that It stoped sudently.

The DFU fails with error (I'm doing the DFU with a M1 Pro. Not sure if incompatible):

"The System cannot be restored on this device.
Gave up waiting for device to transition from DFU state to DFU state.
[com.apple.MobileDevice.MobileRestore -OXFCA (4042)]"

<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> = 5.122V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S</SIGNAL> = 3.294V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> = 2.936V (not sure if the value is normal, but recheked on several places with same value)

<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD</SIGNAL> = 0.9V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD</SIGNAL> = 1.8V

It seams that it is rebooting. It goes from 0.03A to 0.20A, and reboots.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Did you test the board alone on the desk?
CPU core tries to appear?

Check for short and voltage pulse on all big coils.
Inspect audio board/flex for liquid signs.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
I did tested it on the desk alone, without anything else connected, and it has the same  behavior.

CPU core is always stable at 0V.

All big coils seams to be ok, except L7210, L7430 and L7410 that only have 8 ohm to ground and 0.012 on diode reading (again, not sure if normal value) and no pulse.

L7030, L7690 and L7670 have voltages that oscilates whille rebooting

Don't know if it relavant, but the only thing that gets hot is the T2chip, but with only around 33º C, and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> with around 30ºC

Audio board seams ok.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
8 ohm may be good value on CPU coils; better to compare with good board.
Pulsing voltage on mentioned coils means the board tries to start, but some sensor is triggered (overcurrent probably) and power cycles.
Apart of big coils, do same tests at page 67 outputs.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
I don't have other board of those to test it. Do you happen to have these reference values from another diagnosis that you have already made?

I'm not sure if is these that you asked, but my page 67 is about the KB/TP.

L6700 = 3.4M ohm and oscilates bettwen 12.29V to 12.60V
L6701 = 2.2M ohm and steady 3.307V
L6702 = 45K ohm and oscilates bettwen 0V to 3.295V
L6703 = 1.8M ohm and oscilates bettwen 0V to 5.123V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
"my page 67 is about the KB/TP"
Check under "Page", not "CSA" (Power FETs).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Sorry. I haven´t undestood it.

<CHIP>U8240</CHIP> - <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0SW</SIGNAL> = 2.6K ohm and steady 0V

<CHIP>U8210</CHIP> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S</SIGNAL> = 7.28M ohm and Oscilates from 0V to 3.298V

<CHIP>U8220</CHIP> - <SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> = 450K ohm and Oscilates from 0V to 1.803V

<CHIP>U8225</CHIP> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3SSW_SNS</SIGNAL> 0 = 5.2M ohm and 0V

<CHIP>U8200</CHIP> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_X_S0</SIGNAL> = 60K ohm and 0V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Why do you still continue to check in ohm scale for high resistance to ground?
How many times need to repeat about diode mode?
Switch to ohm scale ONLY for very low readings; usually under 0.010...

I don't actually have any 01521 for comparison, sorry.

"<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> = 2.936V"
If true, check <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> too.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
SORRY!
I must have made a mistake and misread it. The actual value of <SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> is oscilating from 0V to 1.802V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Don't catch any pulse at L8100/2?
Trigger <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check; use SWE010 pads.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: I don't catch any pulso on L8100/2 even when trigering  <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> on  SWE010

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Did you try DFU with both charger and battery connected?
Ending with error, may have CPU, or SSD problems.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hi,

Yes, I've tried with and w/o the battery.
